<h1><a id="user-content-description" class="anchor" href="#description" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Description</h1>

<p>In the event of a car accident, there may be limited resources available for dealing with the
ensuing property damage and injuries. In particular, there may be a limited number of people available 
with the ability to deliver high end medical attention if serious injuries have resulted from the accident.
It would be useful if we could predict whether or not a serious injury resulted from the
accident at the time the accident is reported. This could help us decide what kind of medical
personnel should be sent out initially. To this end, 42,183 observations have been collected on
automobile accidents. For each accident you have additional type of information, such as day of week, weather conditions, and road type.</p>

<ul>
<li><code>HOUR_I_R</code>: 1 = rush hour, 0 = not (rush = 6-9 am, 4-7 pm)</li>
<li><code>ALCHL_I</code>: Alcohol involved = 1, not involved = 2</li>
<li><code>ALIGN_I</code>: 1 = straight, 2 = curve</li>
<li><code>STRATUM_R</code>: 1 = NASS Crashes Involving At Least One Passenger Vehicle (i.e., A Passenger Car, Sport Utility Vehicle, Pickup Truck Or Van) Towed Due To Damage From The Crash Scene And No Medium Or Heavy Trucks Are Involved. 0 = not</li>
<li><code>WRK_ZONE</code>: 1= yes, 0= no</li>
<li><code>WKDY_I_R</code>: 1=weekday, 0=weekend</li>
<li><code>INT_HWY</code>: Interstate? 1=yes, 0= no </li>
<li><code>LGTCON_I_R</code>: Light conditions - 1=day, 2=dark (including dawn/dusk), 3=dark, but lighted,4=dawn or dusk</li>
<li><code>MANCOL_I</code>: 0=no collision, 1=head-on, 2=other form of collision</li>
<li><code>PED_ACC_R</code>: 1=pedestrian/cyclist involved, 0=not</li>
<li><code>RELJCT_I_R</code>: 1=accident at intersection/interchange, 0=not at intersection</li>
<li><code>REL_RWY_R</code>: 1=accident on roadway, 0=not on roadway</li>
<li><code>PROFIL_I_R</code>: 1= level, 0=other</li>
<li><code>SPD_LIM</code>: Speed limit, miles per hour </li>
<li><code>SUR_CON</code>: Surface conditions (1=dry, 2=wet, 3=snow/slush, 4=ice, 5=sand/dirt/oil, 8=other, 9=unknown)</li>
<li><code>TRAF_CON_R</code>: Traffic control device: 0=none, 1=signal, 2=other (sign, officer, ...)</li>
<li><code>TRAF_WAY</code>: 1=two-way traffic, 2=divided hwy, 3=one-way road</li>
<li><code>WEATHER_R</code>: 1=no adverse conditions, 2=rain, snow or other adverse condition</li>
<li><code>INJURY</code>: 1 = yes, 0 = no</li>
</ul>

<h1><a id="user-content-preprocessing" class="anchor" href="#preprocessing" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Preprocessing</h1>

<p>We download the data and preprocess it for our purposes. Original data had some
additional columns that we do not care for at this stage.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>download.file(
    <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ChicagoBoothML/DATA___TransportAccidents/master/Accidents.csv<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,
    <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Accidents.csv<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)
<span class="pl-v">accidents_df</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Accidents.csv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)

<span class="pl-v">n</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> nrow(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>)

<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-v">INJURY</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> rep(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>[<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">MAX_SEV_IR</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>
<span class="pl-v">drops</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>MAX_SEV_IR<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>FATALITIES<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>PRPTYDMG_CRASH<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>NO_INJ_I<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>INJURY_CRASH<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>VEH_INVL<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
<span class="pl-v">accidents_df</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>[, <span class="pl-k">!</span>(names(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>) <span class="pl-k">%in%</span> <span class="pl-smi">drops</span>)]</pre></div>

<p>If we care about making decisions whether to dispatch highly skillful medical staff, some 
information is not going to be available to us. For example, we may know if it is a rush hour or not,
however, we may lack information about whether alcohol was involved or not. It is important to
make sure that variables used to build a classifier are actually available at the time a classifier
is used.</p>

<p>I will drop the following variables from creating a classifies:
<code>ALCHL_I</code>, <code>STRATUM_R</code>, <code>MANCOL_I</code>, <code>PED_ACC_R</code>, <code>SUR_CON</code>, <code>TRAF_CON_R</code></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">drops</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>ALCHL_I<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>STRATUM_R<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>MANCOL_I<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>PED_ACC_R<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>SUR_CON<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRAF_CON_R<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
<span class="pl-v">accidents_df</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>[, <span class="pl-k">!</span>(names(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>) <span class="pl-k">%in%</span> <span class="pl-smi">drops</span>)]</pre></div>

<p>Next, we split data into train and test set. 80% of observations are kept in the training set.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>set.seed(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>)
<span class="pl-v">train_ind</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> sample.int(<span class="pl-smi">n</span>, floor(<span class="pl-c1">0.8</span><span class="pl-k">*</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>))
<span class="pl-v">accidents_df_train</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>[<span class="pl-smi">train_ind</span>,]
<span class="pl-v">accidents_df_test</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>[<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">train_ind</span>,]

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> every variable is categorical variable, tell R that</span>
<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>[] <span class="pl-k">=</span> lapply(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>, <span class="pl-smi">factor</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>[] <span class="pl-k">=</span> lapply(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>, <span class="pl-smi">factor</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Finally, we will need some libraries to perform analyis.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">randomForest</span>)
library(<span class="pl-smi">gbm</span>)
library(<span class="pl-smi">rpart</span>)
library(<span class="pl-smi">rpart.plot</span>)
library(<span class="pl-smi">e1071</span>)   <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> for naive bayes</span></pre></div>

<h1><a id="user-content-predicting-majority-class" class="anchor" href="#predicting-majority-class" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Predicting majority class</h1>

<p>Without any information, we can think of accidents with injuries and 
without injuries as i.i.d. Bernoulli(p).  Our best guess for p is fraction 
of accidents with injuries out of all injuries.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>(<span class="pl-v">tb_INJURY_train</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>))
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> estimated probability of injury</span>
<span class="pl-v">p_INJURY</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">tb_INJURY_train</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>1<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> (sum(<span class="pl-smi">tb_INJURY_train</span>)); print(<span class="pl-smi">p_INJURY</span>)</pre></div>

<p>It seems that the number of accidents with injury and without an injury is about the same.
There are a bit more accidents with injury. Let us see what happens if we predict that every
accident in the test set involves an injury.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">tb_INJURY_test</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-v">predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> rep(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>, nrow(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>)), <span class="pl-v">actual</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)
rownames(<span class="pl-smi">tb_INJURY_test</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
print(<span class="pl-smi">tb_INJURY_test</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Accuracy of this approach would be</p>

<h1><a id="user-content-decision-trees" class="anchor" href="#decision-trees" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Decision Trees</h1>

<p>We start by creating a big tree. </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">big_tree</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> rpart(<span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span><span class="pl-k">~</span>., <span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>, 
                 <span class="pl-v">control</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>rpart.control(<span class="pl-v">minsplit</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>,  
                                       <span class="pl-v">cp</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.0001</span>,    
                                       <span class="pl-v">xval</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>)      
                 )</pre></div>

<p>Next, we investigate <code>cptable</code> to find the a good value for the cp parameter</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>plotcp(<span class="pl-smi">big_tree</span>)
<span class="pl-v">cptable</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> printcp(<span class="pl-smi">big_tree</span>)
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> this is the cp parameter with smallest cv-errror</span>
(<span class="pl-v">index_cp_min</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> which.min(<span class="pl-smi">cptable</span>[,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>xerror<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>]))
(<span class="pl-v">cp_min</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">cptable</span>[ <span class="pl-smi">index_cp_min</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>CP<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> ])   

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> one standard deviation rule </span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> need to find first cp value for which the xerror is below horizontal line on the plot</span>
(<span class="pl-v">val_h</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">cptable</span>[<span class="pl-smi">index_cp_min</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>xerror<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-smi">cptable</span>[<span class="pl-smi">index_cp_min</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>xstd<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>])
(<span class="pl-v">index_cp_std</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Position(<span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-smi">x</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">val_h</span>, <span class="pl-smi">cptable</span>[, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>xerror<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>]))
(<span class="pl-v">cp_std</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">cptable</span>[ <span class="pl-smi">index_cp_std</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>CP<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> ])   </pre></div>

<p>Finally, we use this cp value to prune the big tree.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">optimal.tree</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> prune(<span class="pl-smi">big_tree</span>, <span class="pl-v">cp</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">cp_std</span>)
rpart.plot(<span class="pl-smi">optimal.tree</span>)
length(unique(<span class="pl-smi">optimal.tree</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">where</span>))   <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> number of leaves</span></pre></div>

<p>The following command will obtain predictions for the tree. It directly outputs the 
class label of the test examples.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">optimal_tree_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">optimal.tree</span>, <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>, 
                                   <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>  <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> this parameter tells R to predict classes</span>
                                   )</pre></div>

<p>The optimal tree has the following miss-classification rate  </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>(<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">optimal_tree_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>))  <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> error rate using all variables</span></pre></div>

<p>and the corresponding confusion matrix</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">tb_tree</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-v">predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">optimal_tree_predictions</span>, 
                <span class="pl-v">actual</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)  
rownames(<span class="pl-smi">tb_tree</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_NO_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
print(<span class="pl-smi">tb_tree</span>)</pre></div>

<h1><a id="user-content-naive-bayes-classifier" class="anchor" href="#naive-bayes-classifier" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Naive Bayes classifier</h1>

<p>This is a popular classifier that uses Bayes theorem to make decisions. We will
talk more about this classifier later in the class. This is a linear clasifier.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">nb_model</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> naiveBayes(<span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> ., <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Next, we compute error on test data.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">nb_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">nb_model</span>, <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>) </pre></div>

<p>Miss-classification rate is </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">nb_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)</pre></div>

<p>and the corresponding confusion matrix</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">tb_tree</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-v">predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">nb_test_predictions</span>, 
                <span class="pl-v">actual</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)  
rownames(<span class="pl-smi">tb_tree</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_NO_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
print(<span class="pl-smi">tb_tree</span>)</pre></div>

<p>We can observe that the miss-classification rate is worse compared to 
decision trees. However, notice that the type of predictions is quite different as well.</p>

<h1><a id="user-content-random-forest-model" class="anchor" href="#random-forest-model" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Random Forest Model</h1>

<p>We build a model a random tree model. There are two parameters:</p>

<ul>
<li>number of variables to use when building each tree</li>
<li>total number of trees</li>
</ul>

<p>However, we also control the size of grown trees.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">rffit</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> randomForest(<span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span><span class="pl-k">~</span>.,<span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>,
                     <span class="pl-v">mtry</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">5</span>,
                     <span class="pl-v">ntree</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">500</span>,
                     <span class="pl-v">nodesize</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">50</span>,
                     <span class="pl-v">importance</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">T</span>
                     )

varImpPlot(<span class="pl-smi">rffit</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Out-of-bag error plot</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>plot(<span class="pl-smi">rffit</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">err.rate</span>[,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>OOB<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>], <span class="pl-v">xlab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span># trees<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">ylab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>OOB error<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">cex</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.3</span>)  </pre></div>

<p>We make predictions as usual. </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">rf_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">rffit</span>, <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>)  
(<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">rf_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)) 

<span class="pl-v">tb_rf</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-v">predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">rf_test_predictions</span>, 
                <span class="pl-v">actual</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)  
rownames(<span class="pl-smi">tb_rf</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_NO_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
print(<span class="pl-smi">tb_rf</span>)</pre></div>

<h1><a id="user-content-boosting" class="anchor" href="#boosting" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Boosting</h1>

<p>We build a boosting model. The following parameters are needed:</p>

<ul>
<li>shrinkage parameter $\lambda$</li>
<li>total number of trees</li>
<li>how big trees to build</li>
</ul>

<p>IMPORTANT: The gbm package requires us to use numeric value for Y!</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> we need to make INJURY a numberic variable with values equal to 0 and 1</span>
<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-v">INJURY</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.numeric(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>
<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-v">INJURY</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.numeric(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>

<span class="pl-v">boostfit</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> gbm(<span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span><span class="pl-k">~</span>.,<span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>,
               <span class="pl-v">distribution</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>bernoulli<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,
               <span class="pl-v">interaction.depth</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>,
               <span class="pl-v">n.trees</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">500</span>,
               <span class="pl-v">shrinkage</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>.<span class="pl-c1">2</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Variable importance plot</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">p</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>ncol(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>)<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>
<span class="pl-v">vsum</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>summary(<span class="pl-smi">boostfit</span>, <span class="pl-v">plotit</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">F</span>) <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>this will have the variable importance info</span>

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>write variable importance table</span>
print(<span class="pl-smi">vsum</span>)

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>plot variable importance</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>the package does this automatically, but I did not like the plot</span>
plot(<span class="pl-smi">vsum</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">rel.inf</span>,<span class="pl-v">axes</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">F</span>,<span class="pl-v">pch</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">16</span>,<span class="pl-v">col</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>red<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)
axis(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-v">labels</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">vsum</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">var</span>,<span class="pl-v">at</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-smi">p</span>)
axis(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>)
<span class="pl-k">for</span>(<span class="pl-smi">i</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-smi">p</span>) lines(c(<span class="pl-smi">i</span>,<span class="pl-smi">i</span>),c(<span class="pl-c1">0</span>,<span class="pl-smi">vsum</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">rel.inf</span>[<span class="pl-smi">i</span>]),<span class="pl-v">lwd</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>,<span class="pl-v">col</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>blue<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)</pre></div>

<p>Boosting model predicts probabilities. It is important to specify that you want <code>type = "response"</code></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">boostfit</span>, <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>, <span class="pl-v">n.trees</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">500</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>response<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>) </pre></div>

<p>We tranform the probabilites using a naive threshold of 0.5.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">class0_ind</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>  <span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>  
<span class="pl-v">class1_ind</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>  <span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span> 
<span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span>[<span class="pl-smi">class0_ind</span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>
<span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span>[<span class="pl-smi">class1_ind</span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span>
(<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>))  

<span class="pl-v">tb_rf</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-v">predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span>, 
                   <span class="pl-v">actual</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)  
rownames(<span class="pl-smi">tb_rf</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_NO_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
print(<span class="pl-smi">tb_rf</span>)</pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-try-using-most-important-variables-only" class="anchor" href="#try-using-most-important-variables-only" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Try using most important variables only</h2>

<p>Refit the model</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">accidents_df_train_vs</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train</span>

<span class="pl-v">keeps</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>SPD_LIM<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>MANCOL_I_R<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>REL_RWY_R<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>SUR_COND<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
<span class="pl-v">accidents_df_train_vs</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train_vs</span>[, (names(<span class="pl-smi">accidents_df</span>) <span class="pl-k">%in%</span> <span class="pl-smi">keeps</span>)]

<span class="pl-v">boostfit</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> gbm(<span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span><span class="pl-k">~</span>.,<span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_train_vs</span>,
               <span class="pl-v">distribution</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>bernoulli<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,
               <span class="pl-v">interaction.depth</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>,
               <span class="pl-v">n.trees</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">500</span>,
               <span class="pl-v">shrinkage</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>.<span class="pl-c1">2</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Predict again</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">boostfit</span>, <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span>, <span class="pl-v">n.trees</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">500</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>response<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>) 

<span class="pl-v">class0_ind</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>  <span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>   
<span class="pl-v">class1_ind</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>  <span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span> 
<span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span>[<span class="pl-smi">class0_ind</span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>
<span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span>[<span class="pl-smi">class1_ind</span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span>
(<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>))  

<span class="pl-v">tb_rf</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-v">predictions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">b_test_predictions</span>, 
                   <span class="pl-v">actual</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">accidents_df_test</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">INJURY</span>)  
rownames(<span class="pl-smi">tb_rf</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_NO_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>predict_INJURY<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
print(<span class="pl-smi">tb_rf</span>)</pre></div>
</article>
